transcripts.text: Last week, Bettina wrote a newspaper article criticising the government for appointing a female national suicide officer.  She pointed out that there would be an outcry if a man was appointed head of a leading domestic violence prevention organisation.  This is just the latest move by a government determined to deny the fact that suicide is overwhelmingly a male problem, with six out of eight of our daily suicides taking the lives of men.  The recently released National Suicide Prevention Implementation Plan is proudly gender neutral.  failing to acknowledge that men not only dominate suicide statistics, but offering no special programs to address the unique causes of male suicide, which can differ dramatically from those of women who end their own lives.  And now Christine Morgan is to head up suicide prevention.  She's a mental health expert, but in fact, there's solid evidence that most male suicides are linked not to mental health problems, but to relationship breakup.  There's no way Morgan will promote this connection.  Bettina's article led to a heated interview with Merrick Watts on Radio 2GB as the announcer paraded his feminist sympathies and attempted to discredit her arguments.  Here's the interview.

Bettina Arndt is a sex therapist, a columnist, an author, an advocate for men's rights.  She disagrees with a woman being appointed to suicide prevention advisor because men are overrepresented when it comes to suicide statistics.  She says we need a man in the role instead.
